Graphene oxide grafted hydroxyl-functionalized ionic liquid: A highly efficient catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides Wei-Hong Zhang a Pan-Pan He a Sheng Wu a Jie Xu a Yongxin Li a ⁎ Gen Zhang a Xian-Yong Wei b a Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou 213164, Jiangsu, PR China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology School of Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 PR China b Key Laboratory of Coal Processing and Efficient Utilization (Ministry of Education), China University of Mining & Technology, Xuzhou 221116, Jiangsu, PR China Key Laboratory of Coal Processing and Efficient Utilization (Ministry of Education) China University of Mining & Technology Xuzhou Jiangsu 221116 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A grafted 1-(2-hydroxyl-ethyl)-imidazolium-based ionic liquid (GO-HEIMBr) was developed via immobilizing 2-bromoethanol onto an imidazole-modified graphene oxide, which was prepared in a one-pot process. The physicochemical properties of GO-HEIMBr were characterized by atomic force microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, thermogravimetry analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and elemental analysis. In the solvent-free cycloaddition reactions of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates, GO-HEIMBr exhibited excellent catalytic activities. A maximum yield of the target cyclic carbonate arrived at 99% using 0.35mol% catalysts at 140°C in 4h. In addition, the catalyst could be easily recovered and reused for seven times without significant loss of activity. A possible catalytic mechanism was proposed for the cycloaddition over GO-HEIMBr. Keywords Graphene oxide Hydroxyl ionic liquid Epoxide CO2 Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction The chemical fixation of carbon dioxide (CO2) is a hot topic in current researches, owing to CO2 being an abundant, nontoxic, cheap, and renewable carbon resource for various synthetic transformations [1]. Among them, one of the most flourishing examples is the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates [1,2]. Such products are widely used as aprotic polar solvents, electrolyte components in lithium batteries, raw materials, and intermediates in organic synthesis [3,4]. In the past decades, numerous catalysts have been developed for the cycloaddition reaction, including metal oxides [5], alkali metal halides [6], metal complexes [7], and ionic liquids (ILs) [4,8–11]. Among them, eco-friendly and metal-free ILs have been proved to be the most effective catalysts. Unfortunately, the reactions were conducted in homogeneous systems, which suffered from the difficulty in product purification and catalyst recycling [1,2]. To solve these disadvantages, many efforts have been devoted, including immobilization of ILs into mesoporous silica MCM-41 and SBA-15 [12,13]. Obviously, some drawbacks such as high cost, low hydrothermal stability, and unsatisfactory catalyst reusability, hindered their catalytic applications [13]. Hence, it is very desirable to develop a new support for the immobilization of ILs. Graphene oxide (GO) has attracted much attention in the areas of catalysis and materials science in recent years. It possesses remarkable physicochemical properties, including superior mechanical strength, good hydrothermal stability, high surface area, and low mass transfer resistance, which make GO an ideal support candidate in a heterogeneous process [14,15]. Yang et al. [16] and Karousis et al. [17] immobilized a amine-terminated IL onto the surface of GO by attaching the amine groups of the IL or its precursor to the functional groups (epoxide or carboxyl groups) of GO. However, these IL-grafted GO hybrids were used as electrode materials or optoelectronic devices, rather than as catalysts, due to their low ILs loadings. A grafted technique, in which abundant hydroxyl groups of GO react with organic silanes (e.g., 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane) and silane-containing ILs, is a promising method to enhance IL-loading amount. Therefore, as-prepared IL-grafted GO materials can be used as catalysts for various organic reactions. Movahed et al. [18] prepared a catalyst by anchoring a silane-functionalized IL and its N-heterocyclic carbene palladium complex on GO, and investigated its catalytic performance in the Suzuki reaction. Lan et al. [19] reported that quaternary ammonium-based ILs immobilized on the silane-containing GO exhibited good catalytic activity for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate, but the employed amount of catalyst (0.65mol%) was high. Hence, developing a novel IL-based GO catalyst with high efficiency is of great interest. It is noticeable that the catalytic activity of hydroxyl-functionalized ILs (e.g., 3-(2-hydroxyl-ethyl)-1-alkylimidazolium bromide, HEIMBr) is obviously superior to traditional hydroxyl-free ILs in the cycloaddition reaction [13,20–22]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the synthesis of HEIMBr-grafted GO has not been reported so far. In this work, we synthesized an imidazole-functionalized GO hybrid via the silylanization of GO with 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane, followed by the N-alkylation with imidazole in a one-pot process. Subsequently, GO-HEIMBr catalyst was obtained through the quaternization reaction between 2-bromoethanol and the resultant imidazole-functionalized GO. The catalyst synthesized by this simple method revealed excellent and stable catalytic activity in the solvent-free cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Graphite powder was obtained from Qingdao Huatai Company. 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane with purity of 97% was supplied by Tokyo Chemical Industry Development Co. Ltd, Shanghai. Other reagents and solvents were commercial and used as received. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was utilized to probe the thickness of samples. Before the measurement, the samples dispersed in ethanol were deposited over a Si wafer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a PerkinElmer PHI 5000C spectrometer by using the constant analyzer energy mode and Mg Kα excitation radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer (KBr). Elemental analysis was conducted on a CHN elemental analyzer (FlashEA 1112, Eager 300 Software). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a PerkinElmer TGA 7 apparatus at temperatures ranging from 40 to 700°C at 10°Cmin−1 under nitrogen (10mLmin−1). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The preparation of GO-HEIMBr was shown in Scheme 1 . GO was prepared via a modified Hummers’ method reported in the literature [23,24]. Graphite oxide (100mg) was charged to a mixture of 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (20mmol) and toluene (100mL), followed by treatment in an ultrasonic bath for 1.5h. Ultrasonic irradiation technique can easily exfoliate graphite oxide into GO nanosheets in solvent. The resultant mixture was refluxed and stirred under a nitrogen atmosphere for 24h. Then, 1.43g imidazole (21mmol) was charged into the above suspension with further stirring for 24h. The obtained solid mixture was cooled, filtrated, washed with deionized water (3×50mL) and ethanol (3×50mL) alternately, and dried at 80°C for 12h to produce imidazole-functionalized GO (GO-IM). Subsequently, the resultant GO-IM was mixed with a solution containing 1.5mL 2-bromoethanol (21mmol) and 100mL toluene and refluxed with stirring under a nitrogen atmosphere for 24h. The final GO-HEIMBr product was obtained by similar steps of filtrating, washing, and drying. Accordingly, GO-EIMBr was synthesized using the same method, employing bromoethane instead of 2-bromoethanol. GO-MIMCl was synthesized similarly, using N-methylimidazole instead of imidazole without 2-bromoethanol. 2.3 Typical procedure for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide The cycloaddition reaction of epoxide with CO2 to form cyclic carbonate was performed in a 50mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a thermocouple. In a typical run, the reactor was charged with propylene oxide (PO, 214mmol) and catalyst (0.4g, 0.35mol%). After the reactor was purged three times with CO2 and pressurized to 2.0MPa, the resultant mixture was heated to 140°C and stirred for 4h. At the end of the reaction, the reactor was cooled in an ice water bath and the residual CO2 was slowly vented. After being separated from the catalyst by a centrifuge, the products were analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Lunan SP6890) equipped with a SE-54 capillary column and a FID detector. Analysis conditions were as follows: injection port temperature, 250°C; detector temperature, 250°C; oven temperature program, 60°C, hold for 2min, 50–220°C at a 15°C/min gradient, hold for 10min. The liquid mixture consisted of PO, propylene carbonate (PC), and diol as the possible byproduct originating from the hydrolysis of epoxide with trace H2O. The carbon balance was nearly 100%. The conversion of PO and selectivity to PC was calculated on the ground of an area-normalization method. The PO conversion and selectivity to PC were calculated as follows [2]: Conversion = A f PC PC + A diol f diol A + PO A f PC PC + A diol f diol , ⁡ ⁡ Selectivity = A f PC PC A f PC PC + A diol f diol , where A and f were the peak area of GC, and response factor for each compound. The used catalyst was washed with ethanol three times and dried at 80°C for 12h. The autoclave was charged with PO, CO2, and the recovered catalyst for the next run. The turnover frequency (TOF, mass of PC produced per gram of catalyst per hour) for each catalyst was calculated as follows: , TOF = m PC W cat. × t = n PO × Yield ( PC ) × M PC W cat. × t where n PO, M PC, t, and W cat. were the molar amount (mmol) of PO, formula weight (gmol−1) of PC, reaction time (h), and the mass of overall catalyst (mg), respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 AFM The immobilization of a hydroxyl-functionalized IL on GO was confirmed by several characterization techniques including AFM, FT-IR, XPS, elemental analysis and TGA. As shown in Fig. 1 , the average thickness of individual pristine GO sheets was ca. 0.94nm, corresponding well with the reported thickness found in the literature [25]. For HEIMBr-functionalized GO (GO-HEIMBr), the average thickness of the hybrid sheets was ca. 2.13nm. The thickness was a typical characteristic of functionalized single-layer GO [26]. Moreover, the as-prepared GO-HEIMBr sheets were expected to be thicker owing to the presence of the grafted HEIMBr above and below the GO sheets, as well as the electrostatic repulsion between the GO-HEIMBr sheets [16]. 3.1.2 FT-IR FT-IR spectra of GO, GO-IM, and fresh GO-HEIMBr catalyst are compared in Fig. 2 . For the GO-HEIMBr sample, the profile showed the characteristic peaks of the aliphatic CH stretching vibration (3143, 2934, and 2880cm−1), the silane stretching vibration (1126, 1035, and 642cm−1 attributed to SiOSi, SiOC, and CSi, respectively), and the imidazolium ring stretching vibration (1566 and 1448cm−1) (curve (c)) [4,27]. In contrast, pristine GO did not exhibit the characteristic peaks of those organic groups (curve (a)). These results indicated that HEIMBr was successfully immobilized onto the GO surface. 3.1.3 XPS analysis XPS analysis was used to clarify the surface elemental composition and the valence state of the solid sample. Compared with the full spectrum of GO (ca. 25.4% of the oxygen content), characteristics peaks of Si 2s, Si 2p, Br 3d, and N 1s of the GO-HEIMBr sample clearly appeared (Fig. 3 ). The molar ratio of C:O increased from 2.57 (for GO) to 3.09 (for GO-HEIMBr). These results were attributed to a lower oxygen content of the grafted HEIMBr compared with that of pristine GO. The high-resolution C 1s spectra are illustrated in Fig. S1 in ESI. Generally, the profiles of both GO and GO-HEIMBr can be divided into three characteristic peaks, 284.4, 286.8, and 288.6eV, indexed as CC, CO (COH and COC), and CO groups, respectively [28]. For HEIMBr-grafted GO, the intensity of the CO peaks at 286.8eV clearly decreased due to the appearance of two new peaks. The peaks centered at 285.3 and 285.9eV, which were assigned to COSi and CN groups, respectively. 3.1.4 Elemental analysis The carbon content of pristine GO was 50.64wt%, while 0.01wt% nitrogen content was due to residual sodium nitrate resulting from the GO preparation procedure (Table 1 , entry 1). A GO-IM sample was obtained via a silanization reaction of GO with 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane and a subsequent N-alkylation reaction with imidazole. Compared with GO, the resultant GO-IM sample showed that the carbon content decreased from 50.64% to 42.38% and the hydrogen content increased from 3.21% to 4.47%; this is because that the grafted-IL precursor has less carbon and more hydrogen than pristine GO (entry 2). Notably, the nitrogen content of GO-IM increased from 0.01% to 7.98%, which was a characteristic of the successful grafting of imidazole on GO. After the completion of the quaternization reaction between GO-IM and 2-bromoethanol, the weight fractions of carbon and nitrogen in the resultant GO-HEIMBr hybrid decreased as expected (entry 3). This is due to the fact that 2-bromoethanol has no nitrogen and less carbon than GO-IM. Based on the nitrogen content of GO-HEIMBr, it was calculated that the IL content of the obtained sample was 1.89mmolg−1 (48.9% of the total mass). The high grafting amount of IL demonstrated the abundance of hydroxyl groups on the GO edge and basal plane, which were consistent with the results of the C 1s XPS spectrum of GO. 3.1.5 Thermogravimetry analysis TGA was used to evaluate the thermal stability of a solid material and estimate the content of grafted-IL on the support. TGA profiles of GO and GO-HEIMBr are presented in Fig. 4 . For GO, the initial weight loss below 100°C was about 13.3wt% owing to the removal of adsorbed water. In contrast, GO-HEIMBr showed higher thermal stability than GO, which afforded only 3.4% of weight loss at the temperature range. The weight loss at 100–250°C is attributed to the decomposition of labile oxygen-containing groups (e.g., hydroxyl groups) in GO and alkoxyl groups in 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane [27,29]. For GO-HEIMBr, the weight loss in the range of 100–250°C was almost negligible, indicating that these organic moieties were absent resulting from the condensation between alcoholic hydroxyl groups of GO and methoxyl groups of 3-chloropropyltrimethoxysilane. Subsequently, the loss at 250–460°C was assigned to the successive cleavage of the grafted HEIMBr [13]. The weight loss was ca. 48.7% of the total mass, corresponding to the result (IL grafting amount of 48.9wt%) of elemental analysis (Table 1, entry 3). The above results revealed that GO-HEIMBr could endure about 250°C, much higher than the reaction temperature (140°C) in following catalytic experiments. When the temperature exceeded 460°C, the carbon skeleton of the samples started to decompose, showing the high thermal stability of the support. 3.2 Catalyst activity PO was chosen as a model substrate to examine the catalytic performances of various catalysts in the cycloaddition of CO2 to form PC (Table 2 ). No PC product was detected without using a catalyst (entry 1). N-Methylimidazole also gave a poor activity for this reaction (entry 2). Moreover, GO was inert for the cycloaddition of CO2 in the absence of any co-catalysts (e.g., tetrabutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) and [BMIM]Br), as reported in literatures [30,31] (entry 3). In sharp contrast, unsupported HEPIMBr was very active, affording above 99% conversion of PO and 100% PC selectivity; corresponding TOF value was 13.6h−1 (entry 4). However, such homogeneous system leads to difficulty in catalyst separation and product purification. As described in literatures [13,22], the anchoring of hydroxyl-functionalized HEIMBr on SBA-15 or a polymer provided about 99% PO conversion at 120°C and 2.5MPa, whereas afforded poor TOFs of 3.6 and 5.0h−1, respectively. Compared with those immobilized-HEIMBr catalysts, GO-HEIMBr showed a good catalytic activity with a higher TOF of 9.0h−1 (entry 8). These results suggest that the GO support contributes greatly to this cycloaddition. The carboxyl groups on the surface of GO could provide efficient synergistic sites in accelerating the ring opening of PO, and thus greatly promoted the cycloaddition. Furthermore, concerning the large molecular sizes of the grafted HEIMBr, a crossing-linking polymer and mesoporous SBA-15 material may inhibit the diffusion of reactants/products in the pores of those materials. Briefly, both the unique layered structure of GO (less diffusion resistance) and the carboxyl groups of GO could contribute to the higher activity of GO-HEIMBr by the synergistic effect. The catalytic performance of GO-HEIMBr was also compared with that of GO grafted with 1-ethylimidazolium bromide (GO-EIMBr) and 1-methylimidazolium chloride (GO-MIMCl). As shown in Table 2, the catalytic activity of GO-EIMBr without hydroxyl groups (TOF 12.1h−1) was lower than that of GO-HEIMBr with hydroxyl groups (TOF 13.5h−1; entries 5 and 6). These above results indicated that the hydroxyl group in the grafted HEIMBr was responsible for the high catalytic performance, which could provide efficient synergistic sites in accelerating the ring opening of epoxide. Furthermore, GO-MIMCl showed a relatively inferior activity than GO-EIMBr (entries 6 and 7) because of the difference in the nucleophilicity of the halide anions. Namely, the nucleophilicity of Br− is higher than that of Cl−, and the anion with higher nucleophilicity is favored for PO conversion [4]. To further investigate the efficiency of GO-HEIMBr for the conversion of PO to PC, the influence of reaction parameters on catalytic performances was investigated and the results are listed in Fig. S2 of ESI. In all of the experiments, PC was detected as the only product. When the dosage of GO-HEIMBr was raised from 0.1g to 0.4g, the PC yield increased smoothly from 62% to 99% and thereafter remained almost constant (Fig. S2A). Therefore, 0.4g optimal catalyst amount was obtained, corresponding a less molar ratio 0.0035:1 of the catalyst to PO (catalyst 0.756mmol to PO 214mmol). The results showed that the amount of catalyst had a significant effect on PO conversion. The relationship between PO conversion and the reaction temperature was also examined (Fig. S2B). When the reaction temperature increased from 100°C to 140°C, PO conversion increased from 48% to 99%. At 140°C, the reaction rate was close to the reaction equilibrium rate. Consequently, it was found that PO conversion leveled off when the temperature increased to 150°C. Although higher temperatures facilitated the improvement of the reaction rate, it was noted that the CO2 solubility in PO decreased. Herein, it was suggested that 140°C was a suitable reaction temperature. The influence of initial CO2 pressure on PC yield is shown in Fig. S2C. At 1.5MPa, the PC yield was 97% and achieved 99% at 2.0MPa. However, further increase in the pressure to 3.0MPa caused a significant decline in PO conversion. Such an effect of CO2 pressure on the cycloaddition has also been observed in other catalytic systems [4,22]. Based on those literatures, it could be explained that the solubility of CO2 in PO increased with the rise of CO2 pressure, and thus resulted in the acceleration of the PC formation concerning that CO2 was a reactant. Because PO was also a reactant, excessively high CO2 pressures would dilute PO concentration in the vicinity of the catalyst, thus leading to a lower catalytic activity. Consequently, 2.0MPa was the optimum CO2 pressure affording the maximum PC yield. The effects of reaction time were further investigated (Fig. S2D). When the reaction time increased from 1 to 4h, the reaction rate increased smoothly and reached 99% of the maximum PO conversion. The results showed that the reaction time of 4h was sufficient to complete the PO transformation at 2.0MPa and 140°C. In summary, optimal reaction conditions were obtained to achieve the highest PC yield at the catalyst 0.4g, initial CO2 pressure 2.0MPa, reaction temperature 140°C, and reaction time 4h. To verify the versatility for the synthesis of various cyclic carbonates over GO-HEIMBr, the CO2 cycloadditions of several epoxides were carried out at 140°C and 2.0MPa. As shown in Table S1, all of the selected epoxides with electron-donating groups and electron-withdrawing groups provided high yields and selectivity of the target cyclic carbonates. In particular, epichlorohydrin was more reactive than other epoxides, affording 93% yield of the target cyclic carbonate within 1h. The possible reason is that the presence of the electron-withdrawing chloromethyl group in epichlorohydrin favors the nucleophilic attack of Br−, increasing the ring opening rate. The GO-HEIMBr hybrid was proved to be an efficient heterogeneous catalyst in a series of the CO2 cycloaddition reactions. Because recyclability is an important characteristic of heterogeneous catalysts, an experiment using the same catalyst seven times (0.4g catalyst in the first run) was conducted at 2.0MPa and 120°C for 4h. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. After drying, the catalyst was reused for the next run. In each cycle, the PC selectivity remained constant (100%), and the PC yields changed only slightly after seven runs (as shown in Fig. S3). Also, the recovered catalyst was characterized by AFM (Fig. S5), FT-IR (Fig. S4), and elemental analysis (Table 1, entry 4) techniques. There was no significant difference between the fresh and reused catalyst, suggesting a very durable catalyst structure for catalyzing the reaction. 3.3 Comparison of the catalytic performance of various heterogeneous catalysts Table 3 lists the performances of numerous heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literatures. With respect to the TOF data of catalysts, the activity of GO-HEIMBr was superior to each of the listed catalysts. Specifically, it should be noted that the reusability of HEIMBr-immobilized on SBA-15 as well as HFPIL polymer-supported on 4Å molecular sieves was not satisfactory (entries 1 and 4). Besides inorganic materials, polymers also serve as supports for ILs (entries 2 and 3). However, these polymers suffer from a lack of mechanical strength and thermal stability, and deactivation problem caused by swelling, which hinder their application in the CO2 transformation. Luo et al. [31] reported that the catalytic system GO/[BMIm]Br showed a high catalytic activity for the synthesis of PC. However, a large amount (2.5mol%) of homogenous [BMIm]Br catalyst was employed in each recycling experiment (entry 5). In addition, compared with GO-DMEDA-I catalyst, GO-HEIMBr was very active at a lower catalyst dosage in reaction mixture (entries 6 and 7). In our previous work, we synthesized a mesoporous carbon nitride (mp-C3N4) immobilized n-bromobutane (n-butBr/mp-C3N4) material for catalyzing this reaction [32]. Compared to GO-HEIMBr, not only the catalytic activity of n-butBr/mp-C3N4 (TOF 10.7h−1) was inferior to the present study (TOF 13.5h−1), but also the preparation of mp-C3N4 was time-consuming and not environmentally benign (entries 8 and 9). Taking into account the cost, performance, and stability, it can be concluded that our catalyst GO-HEIMBr is more efficient than the listed heterogeneous catalysts. Therefore, the comparison in Table 3 strongly suggests that the HEIMBr-grafted GO hybrid can be used as a promising catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. 3.4 Reaction mechanism According to previous reports [1,9,31,33] and the results obtained, a possible mechanism towards the CO2 cycloaddition reaction is proposed in Scheme S1. A ring-opening reaction is the key to the overall reaction. For GO-HEIMBr of this study, hydrogen bonds are formed between the H atoms of functional groups (hydroxyl and carboxyl groups) in the catalyst and the O atom of epoxide, and meanwhile a nucleophilic attack by the bromine anion in the catalyst on the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of the epoxide. The ring of the epoxide is easier to open to generate a bromoalkoxy complex (step 1). Subsequently, CO2 inserts into the complex to form a bromocarbonate complex (step 2). Finally, an intramolecular ring-closure would result in the formation of cyclic carbonate and the regeneration of the catalyst (step 3). This mechanism is helpful to explain the extraordinary activity of GO-HEIMBr catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this work, GO-HEIMBr was synthesized by grafting 2-bromoethanol onto the imidazole-functionalized GO, which was prepared in a one-pot approach. The as-synthesized GO-HEIMBr catalyst has been demonstrated to be a highly efficient catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition reactions under solvent- and metal-free conditions, affording the target cyclic carbonates in very high yields and selectivity. In addition, GO-HEIMBr could be reused for seven times without significant loss of activity. The high activity and convenience in product separation and catalyst recycling will stimulate future research on developing different types of IL-grafted GO catalysts for CO2 transformation reactions. Acknowledgments This work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (21376032) and Open Foundation of Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Fine Petrochemical Engineering. coredata.dc:description: A grafted 1-(2-hydroxyl-ethyl)-imidazolium-based ionic liquid (GO-HEIMBr) was developed via immobilizing 2-bromoethanol onto an imidazole-modified graphene oxide, which was prepared in a one-pot process. The physicochemical properties of GO-HEIMBr were characterized by atomic force microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, thermogravimetry analysis, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and elemental analysis. In the solvent-free cycloaddition reactions of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates, GO-HEIMBr exhibited excellent catalytic activities. A maximum yield of the target cyclic carbonate arrived at 99% using 0.35mol% catalysts at 140°C in 4h. In addition, the catalyst could be easily recovered and reused for seven times without significant loss of activity. A possible catalytic mechanism was proposed for the cycloaddition over GO-HEIMBr.
coredata.dc:title: Graphene oxide grafted hydroxyl-functionalized ionic liquid: A highly efficient catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides
